Authors: Heymans J.J., Guénette S., Christensen V.
Title: Evaluating network analysis indicators of ecosystem status in the Gulf of Alaska
Source title: Ecosystems
Affiliations: Scottish Association for Marine Science, Dunstaffnage Marine Laboratory, Dunbeg, Oban PA 37 1QA, United Kingdom; University of British Columbia, Fisheries Centre, 2202 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Heymans, J.J., Scottish Association for Marine Science, Dunstaffnage Marine Laboratory, Dunbeg, Oban PA 37 1QA, United Kingdom; Guénette, S., University of British Columbia, Fisheries Centre, 2202 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada; Christensen, V., University of British Columbia, Fisheries Centre, 2202 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada
Abstract: This is the first study on the emergent properties for empirical ecosystem models that have been validated by time series information. Ecosystem models of the western and central Aleutian Islands and Southeast Alaska were used to examine indices of ecosystem status generated from network analysis and incorporated into Ecopath with Ecosim. Dynamic simulations of the two ecosystems over the past 40 years were employed to examine if these indices reflect the dissimilar changes that occurred in the ecosystems. The results showed that the total systems throughput (TST) and ascendancy (A) followed the climate change signature (Pacific decadal oscillation, PDO) in both ecosystems, whereas the redundancy (R) followed the inverse trend. The different trajectories for important species such as Steller sea lions (Eumetopias jubatus), Atka mackerel (Pleurogrammus monopterygius), pollock (Theragra chalcograma), herring (Clupea pallasii), Pacific cod (Gadus macrocephalus) and halibut (Hippoglossus stenolepis) were noticeable in the Finn cycling index (FCI), entropy (H) and average mutual information (AMI): not showing large change during the time that the Stellers sea lions, herring, Pacific cod, halibut and arrowtooth flounder (Atheresthes stomias) increased in Southeast Alaska, but showing large declines during the decline of Steller sea lions, sharks, Atka mackerel and arrowtooth flounder in the Aleutians. On the whole, there was a change in the emergent properties of the Aleutians around 1976 that was not seen in Southeast Alaska. Conversely, the emergent properties of both systems showed a change around 1988, which indicated that both systems were unstable after 1988. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
Author Keywords: Ascendancy; Ecopath with Ecosim; Ecosystem indicators; Gulf of Alaska; Network analysis; Redundancy

Authors: Biswas M., Roy P.K., Mazumdar A.
Title: A comparative study of users' perception of wetland regions
Source title: Indian Journal of Environmental Protection
Affiliations: Jadavpur University, School of Water Resources Engineering, Kolkata-700 032, India
Authors with affiliations: Biswas, M., Jadavpur University, School of Water Resources Engineering, Kolkata-700 032, India; Roy, P.K., Jadavpur University, School of Water Resources Engineering, Kolkata-700 032, India; Mazumdar, A., Jadavpur University, School of Water Resources Engineering, Kolkata-700 032, India
Abstract: Several villages are benefited by Bhomra beel and Ramnagar beel located in Nadia district of West Bengal. They constitute a complex ecosystem with various habitats or biotopes. These wetlands provide valuable services to the ecosystem, namely water purification, flood control, biodiversity, and sustaining of livelihoods. In order to make appropriate estimates of these services, ecosystem models are needed .The present paper shows a comparative study of these two wetlands regions across a number of distinct parameters as perceived by the inhabitants. The water quality as tested in the course of this study shows that it is suitable for pisciculture and that these wetlands may be used as an important resource while developing an orderly conservation strategy. © 2007 - Kalpana Corporation.
Author Keywords: Perception; Stakeholder; Water quality; Wetlands

Authors: Briscoe G., De Wilde P.
Title: Digital ecosystems: Evolving service-orientated architectures
Source title: 2006 1st Bio-Inspired Models of Network, Information and Computing Systems, BIONETICS
Affiliations: Intelligent Systems and Networks Group, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London, London, SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Intelligent Systems Lab., School of Mathematical and Computer Science, Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, EH14 4AS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Briscoe, G., Intelligent Systems and Networks Group, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London, London, SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; De Wilde, P., Intelligent Systems Lab., School of Mathematical and Computer Science, Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, EH14 4AS, United Kingdom
Abstract: A novel optimisation technique inspired by natural ecosystems is presented, where the optimisation works at two levels: a first optimisation, migration of services which are distributed in a decentralised peer-to-peer network, operating continuously in time; this process feeds a second optimisation based on evolutionary computing that operates locally on single peers and is aimed at finding solutions to satisfy locally relevant constraints. Through this twofold process, the local search is accelerated and will yield better local optima, because the distributed optimisation already provides a good sampling of the search space by making use of computations already performed in other peers with similar constraints. We call this new distributed optimisation architecture a Digital Ecosystem, an Ecosystem-Orientated Architecture (EOA) created by extending a Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) with Distributed Evolutionary Computing (DEC). The Digital Ecosystem will allow services to recombine and evolve over time, constantly seeking to improve their effectiveness for the user base. Individuals within our Digital Ecosystem will be applications (groups of services), created in response to user requests by using evolutionary optimisation to aggregate the services. These individuals will migrate through the Digital Ecosystem and adapt to find niches where they are useful in fulfilling other user requests. © 2006 IEEE.

Authors: Arndt J.-M., Dibbern J.
Title: Co-innovation in a service oriented strategic network
Source title: Proceedings - 2006 IEEE International Conference on Services Computing, SCC 2006
Affiliations: University of Mannheim, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Arndt, J.-M., University of Mannheim, Germany; Dibbern, J., University of Mannheim, Germany
Abstract: This paper is based on the view that the adoption of service oriented architectures (SOA) by large information system (IS) vendors might push software development towards an industrialized mode of operation. The emergence of such a software ecosystem is analyzed through an innovation perspective. The special nature of software as an intellectual technology, thus being an intangible product as opposed to physical products, is given special emphasis. Since digital products are expensive to produce, but cheap to reproduce, it is argued on the basis of a resource-based view that this ecosystem should not solely be built on the trading of software, but also on the exchange of business knowledge. © 2006 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Computer networks; Information systems; Software engineering; Strategic planning; Web services; Innovation perspective; Service oriented architectures; Strategic network; Innovation

Authors: Barros A.P., Dumas M.
Title: The rise of web service ecosystems
Source title: IT Professional
Affiliations: SAP Research; Faculty of IT, Queensland University of Technology, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Barros, A.P., SAP Research; Dumas, M., Faculty of IT, Queensland University of Technology, Australia
Abstract: An increasing number of organizations are turning to service-oriented architectures (SOAs) to consolidate and repurpose legacy applications and combine them with new applications. The convergence of Internet marketplaces and SOA is enhancing the growth of Web service ecosystems which is a logical collection of Web services whose exposure and access are subject to constraints characteristics of business service delivery. The service consumers in these ecosystems procure services through different distribution and delivery channels, outsourcing service delivery functions such as payment, authentication, and mediation to specialist intermediaries. The first beneficiaries of open procurement of web services are ventures that successfully overcame the dot-com burst. Application servers can serve as a technological analogy to Web service ecosystems where middleware functions facilitate interoperation of application components.
Index Keywords: Computer architecture; Constraint theory; Electronic document identification systems; Information services; Middleware; Societies and institutions; Business services; Outsourcing services; Service-oriented architectures (SOA); Web service ecosystems; World Wide Web
Correspondence Address: Barros, A.P.; SAP Researchemail: alistair.barros@sap.com

Authors: Cisternino V., Corallo A., Solazzo G.
Title: A legal architecture for digital ecosystems
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: e-business Management Section - ISUFI, University of Lecce, via per Monteroni sn, 73100 Lecce, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cisternino, V., e-business Management Section - ISUFI, University of Lecce, via per Monteroni sn, 73100 Lecce, Italy; Corallo, A., e-business Management Section - ISUFI, University of Lecce, via per Monteroni sn, 73100 Lecce, Italy; Solazzo, G., e-business Management Section - ISUFI, University of Lecce, via per Monteroni sn, 73100 Lecce, Italy
Abstract: This work approaches the problem of the lack of competence, certainty in the reciprocal trading and awareness of regulatory issues for Small and Medium Enterprises that cooperate to dynamically exchange resources, applications, services and knowledge in an e-business context. It is presented the approach adopted in the DBE project1, in which it is fundamental to promote and boost trust relations between the DBE-adopters and the potential ones, supporting the creation of services and transactions that will occur respecting local regulatory requirement. In this paper we will show how we addresses the previous requirements to design a legal architecture for digital ecosystems, model the knowledge related to contracts, agreement and regulatory issues, grant effectiveness to the general model by designing and implementing a process for the capture, modification and extension of this knowledge. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2006.

Authors: Galambos G.M.
Title: Services ecosystem
Source title: Proceedings - 2005 IEEE International Conference onServices Computing, SCC 2005
Affiliations: IBM; IBM Global Services Canada, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Galambos, G.M., IBM, IBM Global Services Canada, Canada
Abstract: Services businesses have become very exciting growth opportunities for the industry. How to design, model, and implement business services using IT technology is becoming a challenging issue. With the introduction of Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) and Web services, componentizing enterprises and services based on patterns has paved a way to running a successful services business. In this talk, I will describe the services ecosystem, methodology and supporting techniques used to build, operate, and manage business services © 2005 IEEE.

Authors: Maas G., Marien J.
Title: Service-oriented architectures: Orchestrating the OSDE
Source title: Alcatel Telecommunications Review
Affiliations: Research and Innovation Department, Antwerp, Belgium; Enhanced Applications Research Business Unit, Fixed Solutions Innovation Division, Antwerp, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Maas, G., Research and Innovation Department, Antwerp, Belgium; Marien, J., Enhanced Applications Research Business Unit, Fixed Solutions Innovation Division, Antwerp, Belgium
Abstract: The Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) approach and the ways in which it changes the creation of new services, from both technical and business perspectives, is discussed. SOA provides a framework to normalize Web services exposure, using a set of best practices to achieve a coherent and functional service-oriented environment. It leverages the existing capabilities of the different Service Delivery Platforms by defining a loosely-coupled architecture for the creation, deployment, delivery, and evolution of services. A successful SOA implementation is the key to the establishment of the Open Services Delivery Environment (OSDE) as a true service ecosystem.
Index Keywords: Architecture; Telecommunication services; World Wide Web; Business perspectives; Evolution of services; Service-oriented architectures; User interfaces

Authors: Galambos G.M.
Title: Services ecosystem
Source title: Proceedings - 2005 IEEE International Conference on Web Services, ICWS 2005
Affiliations: IBM, IBM Global Services Canada, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Galambos, G.M., IBM, IBM Global Services Canada, Canada
Abstract: Services businesses have become very exciting growth opportunities for the industry. How to design, model, and implement business services using IT technology is becoming a challenging issue. With the introduction of Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) and Web services, componentizing enterprises and services based on patterns has paved a way to running a successful services business. In this talk, I will describe the services ecosystem, methodology and supporting techniques used to build, operate, and manage business services.
Index Keywords: Business services; Service Oriented Architecture (SOA); Services ecosystem; Computer architecture; Industrial economics; Information services; Industrial management

Conference name: 2005 IEEE International Conference on Web Services, ICWS 2005
Abbreviated Source Title: Proc. IEEE Int. Conf. Web Serv.

Authors: Walker R.L.
Title: Hierarchical task topology for retrieving information from within a simulated information ecosystem
Source title: Journal of Network and Computer Applications
Affiliations: Tapicu, Inc., P.O. Box 88492, Los Angeles, CA 90009, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walker, R.L., Tapicu, Inc., P.O. Box 88492, Los Angeles, CA 90009, United States
Abstract: The design focus of the Tocorime Apicu integrated search engine builds upon new approaches and techniques associated with evolutionary computation to improve the precision and recall mechanisms of existing information retrieval systems within popular search engines. The interactions of the four major components of engines are facilitated through the use of a hierarchical communication topology which partitions the nodes of a distributed computing system into subclusters. The hierarchical communication topology is based on an information ecosystem modeled upon and incorporating the social structure of honeybees, and thus provides mechanisms for the efficient sharing of information. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Hierarchical task topology; Information ecosystem; Information retrieval; Search engine
Index Keywords: Distributed computer systems; HTML; Information analysis; Search engines; Topology; Hierarchical task topology; Honeybee colonies; Information ecosystems; Information retrieval
Funding Text: The author wishes to express his gratitude to the reviewers whose detailed and useful comments helped tremendously to improve the quality of this paper. This work was supported by Honeybee Technologies and Tapicu, Inc.

Authors: Gren I.-M., Groth K.-H., Sylvén M.
Title: Economic values of Danube floodplains
Source title: Journal of Environmental Management
Affiliations: Beijer International Institute of Ecological Economics, Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, Box 50005, 104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; WWF-Auen Institute, Josefstrasse 1, 76437 Rastatt, Germany; WWF International, Avenue du Mont–Blanc, 1196 Gland, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Gren, I.-M., Beijer International Institute of Ecological Economics, Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, Box 50005, 104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Groth, K.-H., WWF-Auen Institute, Josefstrasse 1, 76437 Rastatt, Germany; Sylvén, M., WWF International, Avenue du Mont–Blanc, 1196 Gland, Switzerland
Abstract: The Danube floodplains are shared by several countries and provide a complex ecosystem with various habitats or biotopes. Three of them have been selected, forests, grasslands and wetlands, which produce services of value to society. Examples of the ecosystem's services are water purification, biodiversity, flood control, wind protection and food supply. In order to make appropriate estimates of these services, ecosystem models are needed to describe how these services are produced and how they are linked to the economies of the countries concerned. Such models are not currently available. Therefore, this study makes rough calculations of values by transferring results obtained in other studies to the Danube floodplains. The services subjected to valuation are provision of input resources, recreation and nutrient purification. The estimated total annual value of the existing Danube floodplains amounts to ECU 374/ha. The total annual value of the entire actual area of Danube floodplains corresponds to ECU 650 million per year. Approximately two-thirds of this value is obtained in Romania. The value of the land as a nutrient sink accounts for about one-half of the total value. It should be noted that the calculations are based on several simplified assumptions and the results must therefore be interpreted with caution. © 1995 Academic Press Ltd.
Author Keywords: Danube; Economic values; Floodplains; Forest; Grassland; Wetlands
